tn.text: Paul has affirmed all men are sinners and continues to remind them that all people are wicked.

The word "therefore" marks a new section of the letter. It also makes a concluding statement based on what Paul said in [[:en:bible:notes:rom:01:32|1:1-32]]. AT: "Since God will punish those who continually sin, he will certainly not excuse your sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Paul is writing here as if he were addressing a Jewish person who is arguing with him. Paul is doing this to teach his audience that God will punish everyone who continually sins, whether Jew or Gentile. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
Here the pronoun "you" is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

Paul uses the word "person" here to scold anyone who might think he can act like God and judge others. AT: "You are just a human being, yet you judge others and say they deserve God's punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: for what you judge in another you condemn in yourself
tn.text: "But you are only judging yourself because you do the same wicked deeds as they do"
Here the pronoun "we" may include Christian believers and also Jews who are not Christians. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: God's judgment is according to truth when it falls on those
tn.text: Here Paul speaks of "God's judgment" as if it were alive and could "fall" on people. AT: "God will judge those people truly and fairly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"the people who do those wicked deeds"
"So" (UDB)
"think about what I am going to tell you"
Use the general word for a human being "whoever you are"

tn.ref: you who judge those who practice such things although you do the same things
tn.text: "you who say someone deserves God's punishment while you do the same wicked deeds"

tn.ref: Will you escape from the judgment of God?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to add emphasis. You can also translate this question as a strong negative statement. AT: "You will certainly not escape God's judgment!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Or do you think so little of the riches of his goodness, his delayed punishment, and his patience ... repentance?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to add emphasis. You can also translate this as a strong statement. AT: "You should not act like it does not matter that God is good and that he patiently waits a long time before he punishes people, so that his goodness will cause them to repent!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: think so little of the riches ... patience
tn.text: "consider the riches ... patience unimportant" or "consider ... not good"

tn.ref: Do you not know that his goodness is meant to lead you to repentance?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to add emphasis. You can also translate this as a strong statement. AT: "You must know that God shows you he is good so that you might repent!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Paul continues to remind the people that all people are wicked.

tn.ref: But it is to the extent of your hardness and unrepentant heart
tn.text: Paul uses a metaphor to compare a person who refuses to obey God to something hard, like a stone. He also uses the metonym "heart" to represent the whole person. AT: "It is because you refuse to listen and repent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is a doublet that you can combine as "unrepentant heart." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: you are storing up for yourself wrath
tn.text: The phrase "storing up" implies a metaphor that usually refers to a person gathering his treasures and putting them in a safe place. Paul says, instead of treasures, that the person is gathering God's punishment. The longer they go without repenting, the more severe the punishment. AT: "you are making your punishment worse" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: on the day of wrath ... the day of the revelation of God's righteous judgment
tn.text: Both of these phrases refer to the same day. AT: "when God shows everyone that he is angry and that he judges all people fairly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"give a fair reward or punishment"

tn.ref: to every person the same measure of his actions
tn.text: "according to what each person has done"
This means that they act in a way that will lead to a positive decision from God on judgment day.
They want God to praise and honor them, and they want to never die.
This refers to physical, not moral, decay.
Though this section is speaking to the non-religious wicked person, Paul sums it up by stating both non-Jews and Jews are wicked before God.
seeking** - "selfish" (UDB) or "only concerned with what makes themselves happy"

tn.ref: disobey the truth but obey unrighteousness
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second intensifies the first. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: wrath and fierce anger will come
tn.text: The words "wrath" and "fierce anger" mean basically the same thing and emphasize God's anger. AT: "God will show his terrible anger" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here the word "wrath" is a metonym that refers to God's severe punishment of wicked people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The words "tribulation" and "distress" mean basically the same thing here and emphasize how bad God's punishment will be. AT: "awful punishments will happen to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here, Paul uses the word "soul" as a synecdoche that refers to the whole person. AT: "upon every person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"has continually done evil things"

tn.ref: to the Jew first, and also to the Greek
tn.text: "God will judge the Jewish people first, and then those who are not Jewish people"
Possible meanings are 1) "first in order of time" or 2) "most certainly"

tn.ref: But praise, honor, and peace will come
tn.text: "But God will give praise, honor, and peace"
"continually does what is good"

tn.ref: to the Jew first, and also to the Greek
tn.text: "God will reward the Jewish people first, and then those who are not Jewish people"
You should translate this the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:rom:02:08|2:9]].

tn.ref: For there is no partiality with God
tn.text: You can translate this in a positive form. AT: "For God treats all people the same" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: For as many as have sinned
tn.text: "For those who have sinned"

tn.ref: without the law will also perish without the law
tn.text: Paul repeats "without the law" to emphasize that it does not matter if people do not know the law of Moses. If they sin, God will judge them. AT: "without knowing the law of Moses will certainly still die spiritually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: and as many as have sinned
tn.text: "And all those who have sinned"

tn.ref: in respect to the law will be judged by the law
tn.text: God will judge sinful people according to his law. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "and who do know the law of Moses, God will judge them according to that law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Paul continues to let the reader know that perfect obedience to God's law is required even for those who never had God's law.
Verses 14 and 15 interrupt Paul's main argument to give the reader extra information. If you have a way to mark an interruption like this in your language, you can use it here.

tn.ref: it is not the hearers of the law
tn.text: Here "the law" refers to the law of Moses. AT: "it is not those who only hear the law of Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"whom God considers righteous"

tn.ref: but it is the doers of the law
tn.text: "but it is those who obey the law of Moses"
You can translate this in an active form. AT: "whom God will accept" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Gentiles, who do not have the law ... are a law to themselves
tn.text: The phrase "law to themselves" is an idiom that means that these people naturally obey God's laws. AT: "have God's laws already inside them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: they do not have the law
tn.text: Here "the law" refers to the law of Moses." AT: "they do not actually have the laws that God gave to Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"By naturally obeying the law they show"

tn.ref: the actions required by the law are written in their hearts
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "God has written on their hearts what the law requires them to do" or "God has shown them what the law requires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: bears witness to them, and their own thoughts either accuse or defend them to themselves
tn.text: Here "bears witness" refers to the knowledge they gain from the law that God has written in their hearts. AT: "tells them if they are disobeying or obeying God's law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: on the day when God will judge
tn.text: This finishes Paul's thought from [[:en:bible:notes:rom:02:13|2:13]]. "This will happen when God judges"
Here begins Paul's discussion that the law the Jews possess actually condemns them because they do not obey it.

tn.ref: Suppose that you call yourself a Jew
tn.text: Here Paul speaks as if he were addressing only one person. What is true for one is true for all people. "Now you think of yourself as a member of the Jewish people"

tn.ref: rest upon the law, rejoice proudly in God
tn.text: The phrase "rest upon the law" is an idiom. Paul speaks of relying on the law as if one could actually lean on it for support. AT: "and you rely on the law of Moses and rejoice proudly because of God"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"and you know God's will"

tn.ref: having been instructed by the law
tn.text: "because you have learned what the law of Moses teaches"

tn.ref: And suppose that you are confident ... and of the truth
tn.text: If your language has a way to mark that 2:19-20 interrupts Paul's main argument of [[:en:bible:notes:rom:02:17|17, 18]] and [[:en:bible:notes:rom:02:21|21]], you can use it here. You might have to place 2:19-20 before 2:17.

tn.ref: that you yourself are a guide of the blind, a light to those who are in darkness
tn.text: Here "a guide of the blind" and "a light" are metaphors for ways of helping a person who cannot see. These two phrases have very similar meanings. Using them, Paul compares a Jewish person teaching someone about the law to helping a person that cannot see. AT: "that you yourself are like a guide to someone who is blind, and you are like a light to someone who is lost in the dark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"you correct those who do wrong"
Here Paul compares those who do not know anything about the law to babies. AT: "and you teach those who do not know the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: and that you have in the law the form of knowledge and of the truth
tn.text: The knowledge of the truth that is in the law comes from God. AT: "because you are sure you understand the truth that God has given in the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: You, then, who teach another, do you not teach yourself?
tn.text: Paul is using a question to scold his listener. You can translate this as a strong negative statement. AT: "You do not teach yourself while you are teaching others!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: You who preach not to steal, do you steal?
tn.text: Paul is using a question to scold his listener. You can translate this as a strong statement. AT: "You tell people not to steal, but you steal!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: You who say not to commit adultery, do you commit adultery?
tn.text: Paul is using a question to scold his listener. You can translate this as a strong statement. AT: "You tell people not to commit adultery, but you commit adultery!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: You who detest idols, do you rob temples?
tn.text: Paul is using a question to scold his listener. You can translate this as a strong statement. AT: "You say you hate idols, but you rob temples!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Possible meanings are 1) "steal items from local pagan temples to sell and make a profit" or 2) "do not send to the Jerusalem temple all the money that is due to God."

tn.ref: You who proudly rejoice in the law, do you dishonor God through your transgression of the law?
tn.text: Paul uses a question to scold his listener. You can translate this as a strong statement. AT: "It is wicked that you claim to be proud of the law, while at the same time you disobey it and bring shame to God!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the name of God is dishonored among the Gentiles
tn.text: You can translate this in an active form. AT: "Your wicked actions bring shame to God in the minds of the Gentiles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "name" is a metonym that refers to the entirety of God, not just his name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Paul continues to show that God, by his law, condemns even the Jews who have God's law.
"I say all of this because being circumcised does benefit you"

tn.ref: if you are a violator of the law
tn.text: "if you do not obey the commandments found in the law"
"it is as though you were no longer circumcised"
"the person who is not circumcised"

tn.ref: keeps the requirements of the law
tn.text: "obeys what God commands in the law"

tn.ref: will not his uncircumcision be considered as circumcision? And will not the one who is naturally uncircumcised judge you ... the law?
tn.text: Paul asks two questions here to emphasize that circumcision is not what makes one right before God. You can translate these questions as statements in an active form. AT: "God will consider him as circumcised. The one who is not physically circumcised ... will judge you ... the law" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This refers to Jewish rituals, such as circumcision, which people can see.
This refers to the physical change to a man's body when someone circumcises him.
This is a synecdoche for the whole body. AT: "body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: he is a Jew who is one inwardly, and circumcision is that of the heart
tn.text: These two phrases have similar meanings. The first phrase, "he is a Jew who is one inwardly," explains the second phrase, "circumcision is that of the heart." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
This refers to the values and motivations of the person whom God has transformed.
Here "heart" is a metonym for the inner person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: in the Spirit, not in the letter
tn.text: Here "letter" is a synecdoche that refers to written Scripture. AT: "through the work of the Holy Spirit, not because you know the Scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to the internal, spiritual part of a person that "God's Spirit" changes (UDB).
